 TENEMENTS STATUS 
 Exploration licenses 08/1567 & 1569 have been granted to Korab Resources Limited on 
 the 4th of August 2006. Korab has lodged applications for Exploration Licences 08/1565-
 1566,  1568  &  1570-1574  which  are  either  contiguous  with  or  adjacent  to  Exploration

 Korab  is  responsible  for  management,  exploration  and  reporting  activities  carried  out 
 upon Exploration Licences 08/1567 & 1569.

text:
Dolomite,  and  Ashburton  Formation.  The  Beasley  River  Quartzite  lies  uncomformably 
 on  the  Archaean  basement,  and  is  overlain  by  tholeiite  Cheela  Springs  Basalt.  The 
 Cheela Springs Basalt is partly overlain by dolomite siltstone and mudstone of the Duck 
 Creek  Dolomite.  The  upper  levels  of  the  Wyloo  Group  comprise  shallow  marine  iron 
 enriched sedimentary rocks (ferruginous conglomerate and siltstone)  
 The  Ashburton  Formation  conformably  overlies  the  Wyloo  Group,  and  consists  of 
 mudstone and sandstone with minor amounts of conglomerate, BIF and chert, dolomite, 
 and  mafic  to  felsic  volcanic  rocks.  The  Capricorn  Group  overlies  the  Ashburton 
 Formation  with  a  prominent  angular  unconformity.  It  comprises  of  shallow-marine 
 coarse sandstones, siltstones, and minor conglomerate and dolomite with minor felsic 
 tuff  layers.  The  Ashburton  Formation  and  Capricorn  Group  are  overlapped  by 
 sedimentary  rocks  of  the  Mount  Minnie  Group,  Bresnahan  Group  and  Bangemall 
 Supergroups 
 The  lower  succession  on  the  northern  margin  is  marked  by  an  earlier  series  of 
 deformations  associated  with  the  Opthalmia  Fold  Belt.  In  the  central  and  southern 
 sections of the Ashburton Province, two phases of deformation are recognized. 
 Ashburton basin was probably formed in a result of oblique collision between the Pilbara 
 and Yilgarn Cratons that took place in the east and migrated westwards. Uplift of the 
 Sylvania Inlier supplied granitic sediment to the Ashburton Formation in the Ashburton 
 Basin.  Initial  deformation  and  thrusting  of  the  Ashburton  Basin  formed  the  Ashburton 
 Fold Belt. Associated uplift caused formation of sedimentary succession of the Mount 
 Minnie Group and the Capricorn Formation. Later deformation was related to extrusion 
 in  the  western  part  of  the  structure  and  development  of  dextral  wrench-fault  system 
 along the margin between the Pilbara and Yilgarn Cratons. The orientation of the fault 
 system  along  the  Pilbara  Craton  margin  was  controlled  by  existing  rift  structures  that 
 had been formed in Fortescue Group times.

5.text: faulted rocks cut by northeast-trending dolerite dykes. Landsat image between Mt Walt

6.text: and the Wyloo Dome demonstrate a north-northwest trending regional scale structural

7.text: corridor  (fault  or  shear  zone)  that  is  considered  as  a  possible  source  of  ore  bearing

9.text: Uranium  mineralisation  is  widespread  in  the  area  as  small  calcrete  deposits.  At

10.text: Mundong Well and Hooley Camp, initial uranium mineralisation occurs as veins in shear

11.text: zones in granite and gneiss of the Wyloo Group. Uranium associates with copper, lead

12.text: and  zinc  sulphides  with  trace  amount  of  gold  and  silver.  Numerous  structural  targets

13.text: have been delineated along the unconformable contact of the Ashburton Formation with

15.text: The  Ashburton-Gascoyne  area  is  also  considered  prospective  for  unconformity  type

16.text: uranium mineralisation. Development and preservation of unconformities within and at

17.text: the  base  of  the  sedimentary  sequence  may  provide  a  suitable  host  for  uranium  rich

18.text: fluids  migrating  along  the  red  bed/basement  unconformity,  with  localisation  of

19.text: mineralisation  at  faults  and  basement  highs.    Potential  also  exists  for  hematite  rich

20.text: banded iron formations within the sedimentary package.

21.text: Gold  deposits  (Xanadu,  etc)  of  the  Ashburton  basin  are  structurally  controlled  by

22.text: northwest-trending  fault  system,  and  occur  as  a  result  of  fluid  flow  through  structural

23.text: conduits  and  deposited  on  the  geochemical  barriers  within  the  Ashburton  Formation.

24.text: Gold  mineralization  occurs  in  quartz-sulphide  veins  and  altered  mineralised  zones  in

25.text: sedimentary  rocks  (conglomerates,  sandstones,  dolomites),  and  is  controlled  by

26.text: structural fluid channels and litological contrast zones.  Upper levels (up to 50-100 m to

27.text: the depth) comprise fractured goethite ores in deeply weathered sedimentary sequence.

text:
faulted rocks cut by northeast-trending dolerite dykes. Landsat image between Mt Walt 
 and the Wyloo Dome demonstrate a north-northwest trending regional scale structural 
 corridor  (fault  or  shear  zone)  that  is  considered  as  a  possible  source  of  ore  bearing 
 Uranium  mineralisation  is  widespread  in  the  area  as  small  calcrete  deposits.  At 
 Mundong Well and Hooley Camp, initial uranium mineralisation occurs as veins in shear 
 zones in granite and gneiss of the Wyloo Group. Uranium associates with copper, lead 
 and  zinc  sulphides  with  trace  amount  of  gold  and  silver.  Numerous  structural  targets 
 have been delineated along the unconformable contact of the Ashburton Formation with 
 the overlying Capricorn Formation  
 The  Ashburton-Gascoyne  area  is  also  considered  prospective  for  unconformity  type 
 uranium mineralisation. Development and preservation of unconformities within and at 
 the  base  of  the  sedimentary  sequence  may  provide  a  suitable  host  for  uranium  rich 
 fluids  migrating  along  the  red  bed/basement  unconformity,  with  localisation  of 
 mineralisation  at  faults  and  basement  highs.    Potential  also  exists  for  hematite  rich 
 banded iron formations within the sedimentary package. 
 Gold  deposits  (Xanadu,  etc)  of  the  Ashburton  basin  are  structurally  controlled  by 
 northwest-trending  fault  system,  and  occur  as  a  result  of  fluid  flow  through  structural 
 conduits  and  deposited  on  the  geochemical  barriers  within  the  Ashburton  Formation. 
 Gold  mineralization  occurs  in  quartz-sulphide  veins  and  altered  mineralised  zones  in 
 sedimentary  rocks  (conglomerates,  sandstones,  dolomites),  and  is  controlled  by 
 structural fluid channels and litological contrast zones.  Upper levels (up to 50-100 m to 
 the depth) comprise fractured goethite ores in deeply weathered sedimentary sequence.
